title: 104_hr2174
content: The Act is titled the "Commission on Missing-in-Action and Prisoners of War in Southeast Asia Act" and establishes a Commission for this purpose. The Commission on Missing-in-Action and Prisoners of War in Southeast Asia Act establishes a seven-member Commission, including a Chairperson appointed by the President, members from the Senate and House of Representatives, family members of missing personnel, and a representative from the Department of Defense. The Commission on Missing-in-Action and Prisoners of War in Southeast Asia Act establishes a seven-member Commission, with members appointed by the President, Senate, House of Representatives, family members of missing personnel, and representatives from the Department of Defense and State. Members serve for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled as per original appointment, and they serve without pay but may receive travel expenses. A majority constitutes a quorum for meetings. The Commission shall meet at the call of the Chairperson or a majority of its members, holding its initial meeting within 60 days of completing appointments. SEC. 4. DUTIES OF COMMISSION. The Commission will conduct a study on Vietnam's efforts to locate missing US personnel from the Vietnam era, including cases of individuals known to be alive but not returned. The Commission will study efforts by Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia, and China to locate missing US personnel from the Vietnam era. A report with findings and recommendations is due to Congress by January 1, 1997. SEC. 5. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission may hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, administer oaths, obtain official data from Federal agencies, and receive administrative support services. SEC. 6. STAFF OF COMMISSION. The Commission may appoint staff and procure experts and consultants as necessary. Staff appointments are exempt from certain civil service laws and pay regulations, with a limit on pay rates. SEC. 7. TERMINATION OF COMMISSION. The Commission will end 90 days after submitting its report. SEC. 8. SENSE OF CONGRESS. Congress should hold hearings within 90 days of receiving the report to discuss its findings. Congress should also consider a resolution on maintaining diplomatic relations with Vietnam.
